question.title: How to draw Class diagram of class which includes only main()
question.body:
I have a class with only a main(), but inside that many variables are there. Should I include all those variables inside the main function into class diagram or just specify only:

Class name

nil

+main(String\[\]):void

question_comments.body: [1] You do treat it as a formal language. That makes this question mostly pointless (nobody but academia cares about that sort of thing). But, the answer is trivial: No, you do't include them. Formally, you never include local vars, no matter how important they actually are to gaining an understanding of what you're modelling/building. [2] You go with the useful, subjective definition: Stack Overflow isn't the optiomal place for such a question. We'd need to know way, way more about your structure and what those variables are, and it's going to end up with a vote-to-close: Opinion.

academia loves talking about 'class diagrams'. However, in the real world, few use them, and those that do do not treat class diagrams as a formal language. Which is sensible: You can't run a class diagram, and generating code off of them is a terrible idea. Their purpose is to serve as docs. They are 'good' if an average reader gains a correct idea of how things (are intended to) work when looking at them, and they are 'useless' if the reader is no closer to understanding, and 'terrible' if they mislead. But that's a subjective thing. Thus, two options, both them easy answers:
If your main does so much you want to show it in a diagram, it probably does too much. Perhaps you should split it into separate functions and display those?
no, local variables are not part of class diagram
